channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: LAPD spent $40 million during protests, coronavirus; officer overtime pay is curtailed
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: LAPD spent more than $40 million in policing George Floyd protests as well as dealing with fallout from the coronavirus, running out of overtime money.
item.content:encoded: LAPD spent more than $40 million in policing George Floyd protests as well as dealing with fallout from the coronavirus, running out of overtime money.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: LAPD arrive to arrests protestors for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UCLA to reopen with mainly online classes because of the coronavirus, officials say
item.dc:creator: Paloma Esquivel
item.description: UCLA described some of its plans for classes in the Fall.
item.content:encoded: UCLA described some of its plans for classes in the Fall.

media:content.media:description: A student walks in the courtyard in front of Royce Hall on the UCLA campus in Westwood on August 7, 2013.

item.title: Fort Bragg, a California city named for a Confederate general, considers changing its name
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: The City Council of Fort Bragg, Calif., named for a Confederate general and slave owner, will discuss putting a name change on the November ballot.
item.content:encoded: The City Council of Fort Bragg, Calif., named for a Confederate general and slave owner, will discuss putting a name change on the November ballot.

media:content.media:description: Fort Bragg is ridden with unkempt Western history but relatively free of kitschy souvenir shops and commemorative plaques.

item.title: Evacuations underway as wildfire burns near Avila Beach
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth
item.description: A wildfire broke out Monday afternoon near Avila Beach in San Luis Obispo County, prompting authorities to close the 101 Freeway and evacuate residents.
item.content:encoded: A wildfire broke out Monday afternoon near Avila Beach in San Luis Obispo County, prompting authorities to close the 101 Freeway and evacuate residents.

item.title: No California budget deal yet as Newsom, lawmakers approach big deadlines
item.dc:creator: John Myers
item.description: The state Senate and Assembly met the minimum constitutional standard for an approved budget to ensure that legislators won't forfeit any of their pay, though negotiations with Gov. Gavin Newsom will continue.
item.content:encoded: The state Senate and Assembly met the minimum constitutional standard for an approved budget to ensure that legislators won't forfeit any of their pay, though negotiations with Gov. Gavin Newsom will continue.

media:content.media:description: Assemblyman Phil Ting, D-San Francisco, urges lawmakers to approve the state budget plan, at the Capitol in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, June 15, 2020. The Assembly approved the spending plan and sent it to the Senate, but it will likely change as negotiations continue with Gov. Gavin Newsom on how to cover a $54.3 billion deficit. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: Black Lives Matter leaders meet with L.A. politicians, saying 'defund the police'
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Dakota Smith
item.description: The People's Budget effectively calls for the dismantling of the LAPD, with the proceeds devoted to housing, healthcare, mental health, parks and many other services.
item.content:encoded: The People's Budget effectively calls for the dismantling of the LAPD, with the proceeds devoted to housing, healthcare, mental health, parks and many other services.

media:content.media:description: Melina Abdullah, a co-founder of Black Lives Matter-LA.

item.title: Newsom defends California reopening rules even as coronavirus cases rise
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon
item.description: Newsom said COVID-19 hospitalizations in the state remain stable weeks after restrictions started to be modified and maintained that the safeguards in place continue to effectively slow the spread of the coronavirus.
item.content:encoded: Newsom said COVID-19 hospitalizations in the state remain stable weeks after restrictions started to be modified and maintained that the safeguards in place continue to effectively slow the spread of the coronavirus.

media:content.media:description: Gov. Gavin Newsom announces new criteria related to coronavirus hospitalizations and testing that could allow counties to open faster than the state, during a news conference at Mustards Grill in Napa, Calif., Monday May 18, 2020. Newsom says the new criteria could apply to 53 of the state's 58 counties. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Column: I'm Black. I'm gay. The high court proved there's nothing equal about equal rights
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: The Supreme Court ensured workplace protections for gay and transgender Americans, but all told, Monday was a draw for equal rights.
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court ensured workplace protections for gay and transgender Americans, but all told, Monday was a draw for equal rights.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA - JUNE 14, 2020 - - Thousands participate in the All Black Lives Matter solidarity march to mark LGBTQ Pride Month along Hollywood Blvd. in Hollywood on June 14, 2020. The march also honored Tony McDade, a transgender man killed by Tallahassee Police Department officers on May 27. The march is in solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and highlight the contributions of people of color who were instrumental in organizing the LGBT movement, such as Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. The procession started on Hollywood Boulevard at Highland Avenue in Hollywood. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: At least 1,000 L.A. County restaurants not following coronavirus safety rules, inspections show
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Officials visited roughly 2,000 restaurants over the weekend and found that half of them were not in compliance with the county's guidelines.
item.content:encoded: Officials visited roughly 2,000 restaurants over the weekend and found that half of them were not in compliance with the county's guidelines.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 06: Virginia Elwood-Akers of downtown reaches for a glass from the cart being used as a "landing-zone" an area used for safely delivering dishes, utensils, and other items to dine-in guests at Faith & Flower in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, June 6, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. As restrictions are lifted and businesses and the economy start to re-open, restaurants are putting in place rules to ensure proper social distancing and the health and safety of guests. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Golden State Killer suspect agrees to guilty plea in a deal that spares him death penalty
item.dc:creator: Paige St. John
item.description: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., 74, has agreed to admit to scores of crimes for which he is not charged, sources said.
item.content:encoded: Joseph James DeAngelo Jr., 74, has agreed to admit to scores of crimes for which he is not charged, sources said.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 29, 2018, file photo, former police officer Joseph DeAngelo, accused of being the Golden State Killer, stands in a Sacramento, Calif., jail court as a judge weighs how much information to release about his arrest. GEDmatch, a popular online genetics database used to find unknown relatives, has tightened its policies for police usage over privacy concerns, after detectives used the site to track down DeAngelo. (Paul Kitagaki Jr./The Sacramento Bee via AP, Pool, File)

item.title: School police should stop pepper spraying students, L.A. Unified superintendent says
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli
item.description: L.A. Unified Supt. Austin Beutner said he will recommend that the school board eliminate school police use of pepper spray and carotid holds.
item.content:encoded: L.A. Unified Supt. Austin Beutner said he will recommend that the school board eliminate school police use of pepper spray and carotid holds.

item.title: How to avoid a second wave as California coronavirus-related deaths top 5,000
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Health experts say it will take businesses, individual and local governments all working together to make sure there is not a new surge.
item.content:encoded: Health experts say it will take businesses, individual and local governments all working together to make sure there is not a new surge.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 28, 2020. Mannequins wear protective masks in the garment district in downtown Los Angeles on Thursday, May 28, 2020. Most of the area's shops are off to a slow reopening after being shuttered since coronavirus lockdowns were imposed on businesses in March. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ex-USC official to plead guilty in admissions fraud case
item.dc:creator: City News Service
item.description: Hiu Kit David Chong is expected to plead guilty Monday to accepting payments to ensure admission to USC for unqualified international students.
item.content:encoded: Hiu Kit David Chong is expected to plead guilty Monday to accepting payments to ensure admission to USC for unqualified international students.

media:content.media:description: The USC campus. School officials violated federal labor rules by interfering with a high-profile vote to decide whether hundreds of its faculty members should form a union, according to the National Labor Relations Board.

item.title: Loma Linda man arrested on suspicion of drugging and raping girl at hotel
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Investigators think there may be additional victims of the 31-year-old man, who authorities say groomed the girl online.
item.content:encoded: Investigators think there may be additional victims of the 31-year-old man, who authorities say groomed the girl online.

media:content.media:description: Joshua Blackwell-Tallent, 31.

item.title: Authorities vow deeper probe of Robert Fuller's hanging death; attorney general, FBI to monitor inquiry
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Alene Tchekmedyian, Anita Chabria
item.description: Authorities said Monday that the cause of death of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale, has been deferred pending further investigation.
item.content:encoded: Authorities said Monday that the cause of death of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale, has been deferred pending further investigation.

media:content.media:description: Protesters stage a sit-in at Palmdale City Hall as organizers demand justice for Robert Fuller.

item.title: Young Black activists are inspired by past generations. But they've moved beyond 'respectability tactics'
item.dc:creator: Sarah Parvini
item.description: Black demonstrators, many in their teens, 20s and early 30s, have given voice to an ambitious new agenda for social change that goes beyond the "respectability politics" of some previous generations of activists.
item.content:encoded: Black demonstrators, many in their teens, 20s and early 30s, have given voice to an ambitious new agenda for social change that goes beyond the "respectability politics" of some previous generations of activists.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 08: Tyree Boyd-Pates, a historian and museum curator who has used digital advocacy to get out his efforts to educate activists and their allies, including a set of "Freedom Papers" he has emailed out in the aftermath of George Floyd's death, poses for a portrait at his home in Koreatown on Monday, June 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: UC regents unanimously endorse restoring affirmative action
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe
item.description: University of California regents unanimously endorse a state measure to repeal Proposition 209, passed in 1996, clearing the way to restore affirmative action in public education, contracting and employment. The UC president, all 10 campus chancellors, and faculty, graduate and undergraduate governing bodies also support repealing Proposition 209.
item.content:encoded: University of California regents unanimously endorse a state measure to repeal Proposition 209, passed in 1996, clearing the way to restore affirmative action in public education, contracting and employment. The UC president, all 10 campus chancellors, and faculty, graduate and undergraduate governing bodies also support repealing Proposition 209.

media:content.media:description: Alma Soriano, left, a senior at L.A.'s Francisco Bravo Medical Magnet, and Marisol Mendez, right, a senior at the California Academy of Math and Science, were among dozens of Latino high school students who marched on the UCLA campus March 31 in support of increased minority enrollment at University of California campuses. Both students were denied admission to UCLA, although Soriano was accepted to UC Santa Barbara. The march was led by the Coalition to Defend Affirmative Action, Integration and Immigrant Rights and Fight for Equality By Any Means Necessary.

item.title: Column: In the midst of a racial reckoning, I'm wondering: What does whiteness mean?
item.dc:creator: Frank Shyong
item.description: How can you write about something that is everywhere and nowhere at the same time, that influences everything but is rarely directly named or discussed?
item.content:encoded: How can you write about something that is everywhere and nowhere at the same time, that influences everything but is rarely directly named or discussed?

media:content.media:description: HERMOSA BEACH, CA - JUNE 02: Several hundred Black Lives Matter protesters take a knee and hold their fists in the air during a moment of silence to honor George Floyd during a peaceful protest march from Manhattan Beach to Hermosa Beach and return at the Hermosa Beach Pier Plaza Tuesday, June 2, 2020. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Public health funds are needed more than ever but lack 'lobbying muscle' in California
item.dc:creator: Angela Hart
item.description: Public health officials are asking for more money in California's state budget. But unlike some rich and powerful health care interests, they don't have an army of lobbyists to curry favor with lawmakers.
item.content:encoded: Public health officials are asking for more money in California's state budget. But unlike some rich and powerful health care interests, they don't have an army of lobbyists to curry favor with lawmakers.

media:content.media:description: Outside the Statehouse Capitol, in Sacramento, Calif., on July 9, 2015.

item.title: For teen activists, defunding school police has been a decade in the making
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Howard Blume
item.description: For more than a decade, advocates have been pushing to reduce the power of police on campuses. Now, what was a back-burner issue is in the mainstream policy discussion of L.A. Unified.
item.content:encoded: For more than a decade, advocates have been pushing to reduce the power of police on campuses. Now, what was a back-burner issue is in the mainstream policy discussion of L.A. Unified.

media:content.media:description: Sarah Djato, right, listens to speakers during a press conference calling for the removal of police from the Los Angeles school system on Monday, June 8, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA.

item.title: Pepper-sprayed at the White House: "It was the worst feeling in the world"

item.description: Imani Williams, 22, of Fresno recalls pepper spray and being hit with a non-lethal round during a George Floyd protest outside the White House

item.title: How do clowns survive the pandemic? Joke through masks, perform on camera — and disinfect those balloon animals

item.title: Why you're being left in the dark about coronavirus hot spots in your area

item.title: L.A. sheriff touts reform despite a record of fighting transparency, civilian oversight

item.description: L.A. County Sheriff Alex Villanueva has touted his department's transparency and progressive policies, but many records are not forthcoming.

item.title: All Black Lives Matter march calls for LGBTQ rights and racial justice
item.dc:creator: Hailey Branson-Potts, Matt Stiles
item.description: Thousands of people filled the streets of Hollywood and West Hollywood on Sunday, denouncing racial injustice and supporting LGBTQ rights in a march called All Black Lives Matter.
item.content:encoded: Thousands of people filled the streets of Hollywood and West Hollywood on Sunday, denouncing racial injustice and supporting LGBTQ rights in a march called All Black Lives Matter.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD-CA-JUNE 14, 2020: Jason De Puy of West Hollywood wears a face mask that reads "Black Trans Lives Matter" as people fill the street on Hollywood Boulevard during a solidarity march with Refuse Fascism and All Black Lives Matter in Hollywood, California on Sunday, June 14, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Masked transit: Out and about, Angelenos cover up
item.dc:creator: Mel Melcon
item.description: A look at people around the Southland doing their thing, all masked up.
item.content:encoded: A look at people around the Southland doing their thing, all masked up.

media:content.media:description: VENICE, CA-MAY 14, 2020: Ray Grey, 28, of Hollywood, wearing a mask to protect against the coronavirus,rmakes his way along the boardwalk in Venice Beach, on a long board with his dog Poet, a Boston Terrier running alongside. They are from Hollywood. A new rule, announced by Mayor Eric Garcetti on Wednesday, now requires face masks for all outdoor activities. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: California prosecutors routinely strike Black and Latino people from juries, report says
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: In nearly 700 cases involving appeals of jury strikes, prosecutors struck Black prospective jurors in 72% of cases and Latinos in 28%,and appellate courts have failed to rein in the practice, a UC Berkeley study found.
item.content:encoded: In nearly 700 cases involving appeals of jury strikes, prosecutors struck Black prospective jurors in 72% of cases and Latinos in 28%,and appellate courts have failed to rein in the practice, a UC Berkeley study found.

media:content.media:description: The California Supreme Court is reviewing written arguments in a pension case that has attracted national attention.

item.title: Column: Already devastated by the coronavirus, seniors stand to lose again in Newsom's budget
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: COVID-19 hit vulnerable seniors the hardest. But Newsom crippled the economy, hurting programs for needy seniors.
item.content:encoded: COVID-19 hit vulnerable seniors the hardest. But Newsom crippled the economy, hurting programs for needy seniors.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MARCH 19: People line up to oick up food in the Leimert Park neighborhood of Los Angeles, Calif. on Thursday, March 19, 2020. taking to Jim Gilliam recreational Center in Baldwin Village for seniors. The CRSSLA Community Build, INC just launched a community response system of South Los Angeles where people can now check on information regarding on food distribution, medical triage, and emergency services. They are using a three-prong approach. The website: www.crssla.org., a Facebook page, :Coronavirus Community Response System of South LA, and volunteers are going to be passing out fliers. Community Based Organizations, churches and stakeholders have formed a coalition to address community needs of South Los Angeles residents in the wake of the Coronavirus pandemic. (Francine Orr / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man killed, two wounded in Sylmar shooting
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry
item.description: One man was killed and two were wounded during a shooting Sunday night in a residential area of Sylmar, according to authorities.
item.content:encoded: One man was killed and two were wounded during a shooting Sunday night in a residential area of Sylmar, according to authorities.

item.title: Protest blocks westbound lanes of Bay Bridge in San Francisco
item.dc:creator: Laura Newberry

item.content:encoded: As of 5 p.m., all westbound lanes of I-80 were blocked by cars that formed a barrier near Treasure Island, the California Highway Patrol said.

media:content.media:description: Cars drive west on the San Francisco-Oakland Bay Bridge in San Francisco, Tuesday, March 17, 2020. Officials in seven San Francisco Bay Area counties have issued a shelter-in-place mandate affecting about 7 million people, including the city of San Francisco itself. The order says residents must stay inside and venture out only for necessities for three weeks starting Tuesday. (AP Photo/Jeff Chiu)

item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,003 new cases of the coronavirus and 17 related deaths.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Sunday reported 1,003 new cases of the coronavirus and 17 related deaths.

Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Beverly Hills restricts nighttime assemblies after protests 'disrupted the tranquility'

item.title: LAPD violence against George Floyd protests erodes a decade of reforms
item.dc:creator: Joel Rubin
item.description: A decade ago, LAPD won praise for its handling of protests. What happened?
item.content:encoded: A decade ago, LAPD won praise for its handling of protests. What happened?

media:content.media:description: Loomis, Rick –– – 123606.ME.0501.protest.3.RL––Los Angeles, Ca.––KCBS cameraman Carl Stein was hit twice by the LAPD, once in the ribs with a baton when he stopped to shoot with his video camera, the second time he was steamrolled by the police when he stopped to photograph them firing. The LAPD used batons and rubber bullets to control a crowd at MacArthur Park that had gathered at the end of an immigrant rights march that took place on Tuesday afternoon.

item.title: L.A.'s homeless agency faces calls to dissolve ties with police
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes, Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: The petition is the latest eruption of a longstanding debate within the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority over how — or whether — to work with law enforcement.
item.content:encoded: The petition is the latest eruption of a longstanding debate within the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority over how — or whether — to work with law enforcement.

item.title: California's gas tax is going up again. Amid coronavirus, some say now is not the time
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: For the third time in four years, California's gas tax is set to increase on July 1. But some lawmakers are calling for a freeze on the higher levy, citing the financial burden already faced by many residents because of the COVID-19 spawned recession.
item.content:encoded: For the third time in four years, California's gas tax is set to increase on July 1. But some lawmakers are calling for a freeze on the higher levy, citing the financial burden already faced by many residents because of the COVID-19 spawned recession.

item.title: Officials don't see foul play in hanging death of Black man in Victorville, but family has questions
item.dc:creator: Deborah Netburn
item.description: Malcolm Harsch, 38, was found hanging from a tree in Victorville on May 31. Authorities say foul play is not suspected in his death, but his family said they find it hard to accept his death was a suicide.
item.content:encoded: Malcolm Harsch, 38, was found hanging from a tree in Victorville on May 31. Authorities say foul play is not suspected in his death, but his family said they find it hard to accept his death was a suicide.

media:content.media:description: VICTORVILLE-CA-SEPTEMBER 2, 2018: The Victorville housing market has recovered somewhat from the recession, but far less than other areas in Southern California. (Christina House / For The Times)

item.title: Healthcare workers, church group join L.A. police protests Saturday
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Across Los Angeles on Saturday, protesters marched to show outrage over the police killing of George Floyd and demand changes to the system.
item.content:encoded: Across Los Angeles on Saturday, protesters marched to show outrage over the police killing of George Floyd and demand changes to the system.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CALIFORNIA JUNE 13, 2020-"All Black Lives Matter" is painted on Hollywood Blvd in front of the Dolby Theatre in Hollywood Saturday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. County reports 1,568 new coronavirus cases, 58 deaths
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 1,568 new cases of the coronavirus and 58 related deaths, marking the fifth day in a row the county reported more than 1,200 new cases.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County public health officials on Saturday reported 1,568 new cases of the coronavirus and 58 related deaths, marking the fifth day in a row the county reported more than 1,200 new cases.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 10, 2020 - - The graduating Class of 2020 from the New West Charter School toss their caps in the air at Stoner Park in Los Angeles on June 10, 2020. The drive-by graduation ceremony happened a few blocks away from the park at the charter school. The graduation ceremony was suppose to take place at UCLA but due to the coronavirus pandemic had to revert to a drive-by graduation at the charter school. The hat toss was organized by graduate Sage Rousso-Schindler. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Residents evacuated from Pasadena skilled nursing facility after state suspends license
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: More than 60 residents were evacuated from Golden Cross Health Care in Pasadena in part due to the coronavirus outbreak, officials said.
item.content:encoded: More than 60 residents were evacuated from Golden Cross Health Care in Pasadena in part due to the coronavirus outbreak, officials said.

media:content.media:description: Golden Cross Health Care, which reportedly failed to provide residents with adequate care, is at 1450 N. Fair Oaks in Pasadena.

item.title: Supervisor asks attorney general to review death of Black man found hanging in Palmdale
item.dc:creator: Kevin Baxter, Benjamin Oreskes, Kiera Feldman
item.description: Many at Saturday's memorial expressed anger and frustration at Robert Fuller's death and what they see as a rush by authorities to label it a suicide.
item.content:encoded: Many at Saturday's memorial expressed anger and frustration at Robert Fuller's death and what they see as a rush by authorities to label it a suicide.

media:content.media:description: PALMDALE, CA - JUNE 13: Paris Draper, left, leads hundreds of protesters in chants for justice after the death of a young Black man, Robert Fuller, during protest march in Palmdale on Saturday, June 13, 2020 in Palmdale, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Magnitude 3.1 earthquake strikes near Ridgecrest
item.dc:creator: Quakebot
item.description: A magnitude 3.1 earthquake was reported late Friday night 15 miles from Ridgecrest, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.
item.content:encoded: A magnitude 3.1 earthquake was reported late Friday night 15 miles from Ridgecrest, Calif., according to the U.S. Geological Survey.

media:content.media:description: A magnitude 3.1 earthquake struck near Ridgecrest, California on June 12, 2020.

item.title: Column: Defund the police? California is trying to hire more cannabis cops
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: "Defund the police" is the mantra, but California's budget is likely to shift dozens of sworn officers to the Bureau of Cannabis Control — and make way for more.
item.content:encoded: "Defund the police" is the mantra, but California's budget is likely to shift dozens of sworn officers to the Bureau of Cannabis Control — and make way for more.

media:content.media:description: WILMINGTON, CALIF. -- TUESDAY, MAY 14, 2019: After LAPD officers conducted a security sweep of an illegal marijuana dispensary, reporters were offered a view of the illegal business before the Department of Water & Power to shut off water and electricity to the dispensary in Wilmington Tuesday, May 14, 2019. City officials are cracking down, passing an ordinance last month that allows the Department of Water and Power to shut off utilities at unlicensed dispensaries. Photos taken in Wilmington, Calif., on May 14, 2019. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: George Floyd protests reached deep into rural California. The reactions were mixed, sometimes scary
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: Antiracism protests following the death of George Floyd are happening even in rural, mostly-white communities. Along with them have come threats and rumors.
item.content:encoded: Antiracism protests following the death of George Floyd are happening even in rural, mostly-white communities. Along with them have come threats and rumors.

media:content.media:description: Protest in Angels Camp in Calaveras County.

item.title: LAPD packed arrested protesters in confined space for hours, heightening coronavirus risk
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: In Southern California, some ask if the police response might do more to get people sick than the protests themselves.
item.content:encoded: In Southern California, some ask if the police response might do more to get people sick than the protests themselves.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 01: Protestors arrested for violating curfew along Sunset Blvd. at Gower in Hollywood on Monday, June 1, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Black people make up 8% of L.A. population and 34% of its homeless. That's unacceptable
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Will calls for racial justice extend to solving the disproportionate number of homeless Black people?
item.content:encoded: Will calls for racial justice extend to solving the disproportionate number of homeless Black people?

media:content.media:description: A mural on San Julian St. near 6th St. in the heart of skid row in downtown Los Angeles.

item.title: Some social distancing with your Chardonnay? Wineries are reopening across California
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Sonoma County wineries are reopening to an altered landscape
item.content:encoded: Sonoma County wineries are reopening to an altered landscape

media:content.media:description: Wine educator David Mayer pours glasses of 2017 Edizione Pennino Zinfandel for guests at the Inglenook winery Friday, June 12, 2020, in Rutherford, Calif. California wineries started uncorking their bottles and welcoming people back to their tasting rooms Friday as the state's $145 billion tourism industry gears up with hotels, zoos, museums and aquariums also allowed to reopen. The historic winery, which dates to 1879, reopened Friday to wine club members after being closed since mid March because of the coronavirus threat and will be open to the public on June 25. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: California coronavirus surge tied to increase in testing, not reopening businesses, official says
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Anh Do
item.description: California's health secretary announced a new round of reopenings and said increasing daily case counts are probably due to ramped-up testing.
item.content:encoded: California's health secretary announced a new round of reopenings and said increasing daily case counts are probably due to ramped-up testing.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 11, 2020 - Kitson employee Tom Ernst rearranges merchandise displayed to attract walk-by customers on Robertson Boulevard in Los Angeles. While some employees around the U.S. have been squeamish about returning to face to face retail work, Ernst is thrilled to feel needed again and have a place to go outside his home. "It's been so great to be back to work," he said. (Ronald D. White / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Ronald D. White / Los Angeles Times

item.title: Photos of the reopening of Yosemite National Park after coronavirus closure
item.dc:creator: Mary Forgione
item.description: You'll need a reservation to visit Yosemite, even if you're just going for the day.
item.content:encoded: You'll need a reservation to visit Yosemite, even if you're just going for the day.

media:content.media:description: YOSEMITE NATIONAL PARK, CA - JUNE 11: Paddle boarders head out on the Merced River in Yosemite Valley as the park is open for the first time in 2½ months after closing because of the coronavirus on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Yosemite National Park, CA. (Brian van der Brug / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Brian van der Brug/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Los Angeles County officials acknowledge delays in testing at nursing homes
item.dc:creator: Brittny Mejia, Jack Dolan
item.description: Los Angeles County officials have acknowledged that their testing of residents and staff at nursing homes is taking too long, following a Times investigation that found it took the county health department more than a week to provide tests for employees at Norwalk Skilled Nursing & Wellness Center after a resident tested positive.
item.content:encoded: Los Angeles County officials have acknowledged that their testing of residents and staff at nursing homes is taking too long, following a Times investigation that found it took the county health department more than a week to provide tests for employees at Norwalk Skilled Nursing & Wellness Center after a resident tested positive.

media:content.media:description: NORWALK, CA - JUNE 09: In mid-May the Norwalk Skilled Nursing and Wellness Centre (cq) had a resident with COVID-19. The workers weren't tested for more than a week, according to interviews with more than half a dozen employees. Now, at least 40 residents and 30 staff have tested positive. At least five people have died. (Myung J. Chun / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Torrance police identify woman who went on anti-Asian racist tirades
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: Torrance police identified the woman at the center of a social media storm over racist, anti-Asian tirades caught on video as Long Beach resident Lena Hernandez, 56.
item.content:encoded: Torrance police identified the woman at the center of a social media storm over racist, anti-Asian tirades caught on video as Long Beach resident Lena Hernandez, 56.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA-JUNE 12, 2020: Sherry, 38 of Torrance,(she didn't want her last name used), center, acknowledges supporters at the conclusion of a rally and workout titled, "We Sweat With You," at Charles H. Wilson Park in Torrance, where a woman made racist, anti-Asian comments to her, as she was exercising in the park, earlier this week. The same woman made anti-asian comments to an Asian male, 2nd from left, (didn't want to give his name) in the driver's seat of his car parked next to hers. In the car at the time was his 11 year old son, left, and 2 year old son, not pictured. Kayceelyn Salmimnao, 32, of Torrance, 4th from left, with her 8 year old daughter, (didn't want daughter to be named) said that she was physically attacked by the same woman at Del Amo Fashion Center in October. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Nail salons, tattoo shops and massage therapists can reopen next week in some California counties
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Anh Do
item.description: Nail salons, tattoo shops and massage parlors in California will be permitted to start to reopen in a week as the state continues to ease stay-at-home restrictions put in place to slow the spread of the coronavirus, state officials announced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Nail salons, tattoo shops and massage parlors in California will be permitted to start to reopen in a week as the state continues to ease stay-at-home restrictions put in place to slow the spread of the coronavirus, state officials announced Friday.

media:content.media:description: SHER MAN OAKS, CA-MAY 15, 2020: Jaqueline Argelagos of Sherman Oaks, left, wearing a protective mask against the coronavirus, shops for nail polish inside Sherman Oaks Beauty Collection. The store is one of 60 non-essential businesses cited by Los Angeles City Attorney Mike Feuer for "flouting the city's Safer at Home order. Store owner Janet Tavakoli says she shut down her store for 2 weeks, losing $15,000 in sales but reopened after seeing beauty store competitors open. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Students struggle to make campus housing decisions as colleges make reopening plans
item.dc:creator: Lila Seidman
item.description: College students are making fall housing decisions, including whether to sign and break leases, based on limited details of what campus life will look like.
item.content:encoded: College students are making fall housing decisions, including whether to sign and break leases, based on limited details of what campus life will look like.

media:content.media:description: Associate Dean for Students Megan Osborn walks the parking lot before the University of California, Irvine, School of Medicine class of 2020 first ever drive-thru commencement ceremony at the school in Irvine on Saturday, May 30, 2020.

item.title: L.A. youth group demands defunding police, other reforms

item.content:encoded: L.A. youths demand defunding police, other reforms

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: A man holds up a sign with the words "Prosecute Killer Cops, No Justice No, No Peace, Defund the Police," along with about 1,000 people gathered to protest the death of George Floyd and in support of Black Lives Matter, in downtown, Los Angeles, CA, on Friday, June 5, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: The driver, who had been at Metro for 23 years, worked at a downtown bus yard

item.title: Protesters demand investigation after young Black man is found hanging from tree in Palmdale
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Matt Hamilton, Kiera Feldman
item.description: L.A. County sheriff's officials said Friday it appears Robert Fuller died by suicide, though a full autopsy is planned.
item.content:encoded: L.A. County sheriff's officials said Friday it appears Robert Fuller died by suicide, though a full autopsy is planned.

media:content.media:description: The Los Angeles County Sheriff's Department is investigating after the body of 24 year-old Robert Fuller was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale.

item.title: Inmate dies at Chuckawalla Valley, site of worst coronavirus outbreak in prison system
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Matthew Ormseth
item.description: While the prisoner's cause of death has not been confirmed, it appears the man died of complications related to COVID-19, the first coronavirus-related death at the prison.
item.content:encoded: While the prisoner's cause of death has not been confirmed, it appears the man died of complications related to COVID-19, the first coronavirus-related death at the prison.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California is on the cusp of 5,000 COVID-19 deaths as more businesses reopen
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth, Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Both the state and Los Angeles County recorded their largest one-day increases in new COVID-19 cases Thursday.
item.content:encoded: Both the state and Los Angeles County recorded their largest one-day increases in new COVID-19 cases Thursday.

media:content.media:description: COSTA MESA, CA - JUNE 11: Mall employee Glenby Ramirez, right, wipes down the escalator handrail while shopper pass by as South Coast Plaza reopens, requiring customers maintain a social distance and wear face masks at South Coast Plaza Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Costa Mesa, CA. Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Some shun wearing masks even though they're essential coronavirus protection
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Sandhya Kambhampati
item.description: In California, mandatory face coverings that experts say reduce the spread of the coronavirus are at the center of an intense political fight.
item.content:encoded: In California, mandatory face coverings that experts say reduce the spread of the coronavirus are at the center of an intense political fight.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: People walk along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public.

item.title: Nonracist to antiracist: Seven rapid culture shifts since the killing of George Floyd
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Prompted by the police killing of George Floyd, American culture has radically transformed in less than three weeks. Here are seven key shifts.
item.content:encoded: Prompted by the police killing of George Floyd, American culture has radically transformed in less than three weeks. Here are seven key shifts.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 05: Katyana DeCampos, a citizen of France visiting California, marched with a sign with the words "Anti Racism," joining nearly 1,000 people gathered to protest the death of George Floyd and in support of Black Lives Matter, in downtown, Los Angeles, CA, on Friday, June 5, 2020. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Miss the fish? Aquarium of the Pacific in Long Beach reopens this weekend
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: An updated coral reef exhibit will debut. Members can return Friday, and all visitors will be welcome Sunday.
item.content:encoded: An updated coral reef exhibit will debut. Members can return Friday, and all visitors will be welcome Sunday.

media:content.media:description: A seahorse is on display at the Aquarium of the Pacific.

item.title: California lawmakers bristle at Newsom's use of executive power during coronavirus crisis
item.dc:creator: Taryn Luna
item.description: California lawmakers are frustrated with Gov. Gavin Newsom's use of power during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.content:encoded: California lawmakers are frustrated with Gov. Gavin Newsom's use of power during the coronavirus outbreak.

media:content.media:description: Wearing a face mask reading "California safe," Assemblyman Kevin Kiley, right, R-Granite Bay, attends a hearing of the Assembly Transportation Committee in Sacramento, Calif., Monday, May 4, 2020. Assembly members returned to the Capitol on Monday after a nearly six-week layoff due to the coronavirus pandemic. Committee members wore masks, and practiced social distancing by meeting in the Assembly chamber, instead of a smaller hearing room. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli)

item.title: London Breed pushes San Francisco reforms: Police no longer will respond to noncriminal calls
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan
item.description: San Francisco officers will stop responding to disputes between neighbors, reports about homeless people and school discipline interventions.
item.content:encoded: San Francisco officers will stop responding to disputes between neighbors, reports about homeless people and school discipline interventions.

media:content.media:description: In this photo taken June 1, 2020, San Francisco Mayor London Breed speaks to a group protesting police racism outside City Hall in San Francisco. San Francisco police will stop responding to neighbor disputes, reports on homeless people, school discipline interventions and other non-criminal activities as part of a police reform plan announced Thursday, June 11, 2020. Mayor London Breed's said officers would be replaced on non-violent calls by trained and non-armed professionals to limit unnecessary confrontation between the police department and the community. (AP Photo/Eric Risberg)

item.title: Family questions fatal shooting of Lancaster man by sheriff's deputy
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry, Luke Money
item.description: Deputies tried to detain the man, but he refused to comply with their orders and tried to grab a deputy's firearm, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Deputies tried to detain the man, but he refused to comply with their orders and tried to grab a deputy's firearm, authorities said.

item.title: Racism is the reason Black people are disproportionately homeless in L.A., report shows
item.dc:creator: Gale Holland
item.description: Black people make up 8% of L.A., but more than a third of its homeless population, according to the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority's homeless count report released Friday.
item.content:encoded: Black people make up 8% of L.A., but more than a third of its homeless population, according to the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority's homeless count report released Friday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 04: A protestors hands Isaac D., right, homeless, a bottle of water as he watches protestors march in solidarity against last week's death of George Floyd in Minneapolis, in the 2nd Street Tunnel on Thursday, June 4, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Homeless are exempt from the curfew in place for the protesters. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Community college presidents aim to address 'tremendous racial inequities' on campuses

item.content:encoded: The newly formed alliance will train college representatives on topics like hiring and retaining faculty of color, fostering inclusive classrooms and integrating race across the curriculum.

item.content:encoded: Police in Los Angeles and other cities have fired 40-millimeter foam bullets at George Floyd protesters, drawing complaints of excessive force.

item.title: Nearly 160 coronavirus vaccines are in the works. Here's a closer look at the science
item.dc:creator: Thomas Curwen
item.description: The global race for a coronavirus vaccine involves a few basic approaches. Some have been around for decades, others are being tried for the first time.
item.content:encoded: The global race for a coronavirus vaccine involves a few basic approaches. Some have been around for decades, others are being tried for the first time.

media:content.media:description: Vials used to prepare syringes in a safety study of a potential coronavirus vaccine developed by the National Institutes of Health and Moderna Inc.

item.title: Homelessness jumped 13% in L.A. County, 14% in the city before pandemic
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes, Doug Smith
item.description: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars spent to curb homelessness, the number of people without a home in Los Angeles grew for the fifth time in the past six years, officials announced Friday.
item.content:encoded: Despite hundreds of millions of dollars spent to curb homelessness, the number of people without a home in Los Angeles grew for the fifth time in the past six years, officials announced Friday.

media:content.media:description: NORTH HOLLYWOOD, CA - JANUARY 21, 2020 - Gospel musician Clemmie Williams, 34, lives homeless in North Hollywood Park on January 21, 2020. Williams has been working on part time jobs but it's not enough to make first and last for an apartment he says. "It's a struggle to get back to normalcy," Williams said. Williams was photographed on the first night of the 2020 LA County homeless count. On Tuesday, volunteers with the focused on the San Gabriel and San Fernando valleys. Other swaths of the region, such as the South Bay and Antelope Valley, will be covered Wednesday and Thursday.. The homeless count is overseen by the Los Angeles Homeless Services Authority (LAHSA) The volunteers will canvas more than 80 cities and 200 communities across L.A. County over three days to count the number of homeless people living on the streets, according to the LAHSA. Last year's count found that nearly 59,000 people were experiencing homelessness countywide, an increase of 12% from 2018. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Anti-Asian tirades appear to be from the same woman
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa, Hannah Fry
item.description: A woman who gained notoriety making racist, anti-Asian comments on Wednesday used bigoted slurs to an Asian man on Thursday.
item.content:encoded: A woman who gained notoriety making racist, anti-Asian comments on Wednesday used bigoted slurs to an Asian man on Thursday.

item.title: Black attorney accuses ACLU of 'flagrantly racist policies' in discrimination lawsuit
item.dc:creator: Matt Hamilton
item.description: Sarah O. Clifton contends she was labeled as "angry" or "aggressive" for raising racial equity issues while working as an attorney for the ACLU, according to a lawsuit filed this week.
item.content:encoded: Sarah O. Clifton contends she was labeled as "angry" or "aggressive" for raising racial equity issues while working as an attorney for the ACLU, according to a lawsuit filed this week.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 13: Sarah Clifton poses for a portrait in a plaza area in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, June 13, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Clifton, a black attorney who used to work at the ACLU of Southern California but is now suing the organization, alleging racial discrimination and workplace retaliation. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

Although not all stores in the upscale shopping center will resume operations, more than 110 merchants - including Apple, Macy's and Nordstrom - are opening their doors after being closed for three months amid the coronavirus pandemic. item.title: L.A. faces critical coronavirus test: Will reopening more businesses bring serious new outbreaks?
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Among the rules for newly reopened facilities are a limit on capacity, stringent cleaning requirements and a mandate that staff wear face coverings at all times.
item.content:encoded: Among the rules for newly reopened facilities are a limit on capacity, stringent cleaning requirements and a mandate that staff wear face coverings at all times.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE-CA-APRIL 2, 2020: Robert Hennie, 51, an independent filmmaker, sets up a makeshift gym in the children's playground, where caution tape prevents kids from playing, to slow the spread of the coronavirus, at De Portola Park in Torrance on Thursday, April 2, 2020. Californians are finding ways to work out due to gym closures amid the Coronavirus. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: USC removes name of Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics leader, from prominent building
item.dc:creator: Teresa Watanabe, Tomás Mier
item.description: USC has removed the name of former President Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics supporter, from a prominent campus building.
item.content:encoded: USC has removed the name of former President Rufus von KleinSmid, a eugenics supporter, from a prominent campus building.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 11: Rufus B. von KleinSmid's name removed from the University of Southern California International relations building on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. von KleinSmid was the fifth president of the University of Southern California. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Immigration officials bought dirt bikes and boats instead of food and medicine, report says
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo
item.description: Customs and Border Protection officials spent emergency funds meant for immigrant care on dirt bikes, dog food and boats.
item.content:encoded: Customs and Border Protection officials spent emergency funds meant for immigrant care on dirt bikes, dog food and boats.

media:content.media:description: MATAMOROS, MEXICO-MAY 15, 2020-Three-year-old Angie Garcia, originally from El Salvador, washes her hands in a bucket before eating lunch. Her family are asylum seekers living in a refugee camp in Matamoros, Mexico. Hundreds of asylum seekers are waiting under the "Remain in Mexico" program in the camp, where there has yet to be one case of Covid-19 during the pandemic. Sanitation conditions have greatly improved in the camp in the past six months. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Man fed homeless people food laced with chemical stronger than pepper spray, prosecutors say
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: A 38-year-old man is facing multiple felony charges after authorities allege he poisoned eight homeless people in a series of videotaped attacks last month in Orange County.
item.content:encoded: A 38-year-old man is facing multiple felony charges after authorities allege he poisoned eight homeless people in a series of videotaped attacks last month in Orange County.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA -- MONDAY, MAY 11, 2020: Some beach-goers actively use the beach while others relax on the beach, despite Gov. Newsom's active-use-only allowance at the beach in Huntington Beach, CA, on May 11, 2020. The city of Huntington Beach is still pursuing their lawsuit against the state to reopen the beach to all forms of activities - including sun bathing.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Orange County rescinds coronavirus mask mandate amid pushback, resignation
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Stephanie Lai
item.description: 'This does not diminish the importance of face coverings,' Orange County's new health director says in loosening COVID-19 pandemic requirements.
item.content:encoded: 'This does not diminish the importance of face coverings,' Orange County's new health director says in loosening COVID-19 pandemic requirements.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: People walk along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public.

item.title: Graveyard shooting is California town's first homicide in nearly 25 years
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The tiny town of Colma, Calif., where most of the land is taken up by cemeteries, reports its first homicide in nearly 25 years — in a graveyard.
item.content:encoded: The tiny town of Colma, Calif., where most of the land is taken up by cemeteries, reports its first homicide in nearly 25 years — in a graveyard.

media:content.media:description: Estate planning shouldn't be a do-it-yourself project if your holdings are large enough to trigger taxes. Above, Holy Cross Cemetery in Colma, Calif.

item.title: LAPD officer shown in video striking homeless man defends actions, pleads not guilty
item.dc:creator: James Queally
item.description: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez pleads not guilty to assault and defends his actions in a viral video that has sparked allegations of police brutality.
item.content:encoded: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez pleads not guilty to assault and defends his actions in a viral video that has sparked allegations of police brutality.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 11: LAPD Officer Frank Hernandez at arraignment pleaded not guilty to assault charges Thursday after a video showed him repeatedly punching an unarmed homeless man during in Boyle Heights earlier this year. He is due back in court in July. Clara Shortridge Foltz Criminal Justice Center on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Landlord group sues city of L.A. over coronavirus anti-eviction protections
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: The region's largest landlord group says that the city of Los Angeles' eviction moratorium is unconstitutional.
item.content:encoded: The region's largest landlord group says that the city of Los Angeles' eviction moratorium is unconstitutional.

media:content.media:description: Racial slurs and harassment by another tenant can amount to discrimination under fair-housing laws.

item.title: Arrest records of protesters who weren't charged should be destroyed, lawyers say
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: Protesters arrested for curfew violations in Los Angeles aren't being charged, so their records should be sealed and destroyed, their lawyers say.
item.content:encoded: Protesters arrested for curfew violations in Los Angeles aren't being charged, so their records should be sealed and destroyed, their lawyers say.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: Arrests made for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Coronavirus transmissions keep rising in L.A. County, bringing new dangers for hospitals
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II, Colleen Shalby
item.description: There is a chance that the nation's most populous county could run out of intensive care unit beds in two to four weeks, officials said Wednesday.
item.content:encoded: There is a chance that the nation's most populous county could run out of intensive care unit beds in two to four weeks, officials said Wednesday.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 10: A man peddles along the Venice Beach Boardwalk on Wednesday, June 10, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Hot weather is in the Southland today with a heat advisory in effect until 7 p.m.. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Human remains recovered at Mt. Baldy three months after hiker went missing
item.dc:creator: Dorany Pineda
item.description: In late March, a 72-year-old L.A. County man left home for a hike on Mt. Baldy and never returned. Human remains were found over the weekend.
item.content:encoded: In late March, a 72-year-old L.A. County man left home for a hike on Mt. Baldy and never returned. Human remains were found over the weekend.

media:content.media:description: In this file photo, a view of snow–covered Mt. Baldy. On Saturday, a 47-year-old man slipped and fell from a trail on the mountain and later died.

item.title: Lime fire burns 450 acres in Ventura County hills as firefighters try to gain the upper hand
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The brush fire in the hills around Lake Piru is 20% contained, while the Elizabeth fire between Ventura and Santa Paula is 70% contained.
item.content:encoded: The brush fire in the hills around Lake Piru is 20% contained, while the Elizabeth fire between Ventura and Santa Paula is 70% contained.

media:content.media:description: Firefighters battle the 200-acre Lime Fire near Lake Piru in Ventura County on June 10, 2020. (Ventura County Fire Dept.)

item.title: Gunman dead, 3 officers shot as Paso Robles manhunt comes to violent end
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill, Richard Winton
item.description: Mason James Lira is suspected of fatally shooting a Paso Robles man and wounding a sheriff's deputy early Wednesday, authorities said.
item.content:encoded: Mason James Lira is suspected of fatally shooting a Paso Robles man and wounding a sheriff's deputy early Wednesday, authorities said.

media:content.media:description: An image taken from a surveillance camera shows a suspected gunman.
media:content.media:credit: San Luis Obispo County Sheriff's Office via Associated Press

item.title: 'They will try to divide us': Protesters demand real accountability for police, prosecutors
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Oreskes
item.description: Hundreds of protestors gathered Wednesday decry the practices of police and politicians like Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey and President Trump.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of protestors gathered Wednesday decry the practices of police and politicians like Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey and President Trump.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - JUNE 10, 2020. A shell casing serves as a vase for flowers on the sidewalk outside the L.A. County Hall of Justice in downtown Los Angeles on Wednesday, June 10, 2020. Hundreds of Black Lives Matter Los Angeles members and their supporters called for an end to the tenure of Los Angeles District Attorney Jackie Lacey over her alleged failure to prosecute officer-involved killings. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)
